awd_titl_txt: Full-Scale Development: Secrets of the Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
This research and development project would inform and engage audiences (especially middle school age girls) about the fundamental research under investigation at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland. A research plan and summative evaluation will fill a gap in what is known about the public's perception and understanding of the LHC/particle physics and include studies on girl's interest and engagement.   

Deliverables include a 40 minute giant screen film (3D/2D), full dome planetarium film, an interactive theater lobby exhibit, website, mobile app, materials and professional development workshops for educators.  The giant screen film will use scientific visualizations and artistic interpretation to reveal compelling scientific stories recreating conditions following the Big Bang and the discovery in 2012 of the Higgs boson.  CERN is providing unprecedented access to the collider and particle detectors including filming inside the 17 mile long underground tunnel while it is closed for upgrades in 2013-2014. 

There are 8 partner science museums (7 with planetariums) that will show the film/exhibit and serve as sites for research, evaluation, and outreach to underserved audiences ( Adventure Science Center, Carnegie Science Center, The Franklin Institute, Liberty Science Center, OMSI, Orlando Science Center, the Smithsonian, and the St. Louis Science Center). Additional distribution/marketing channels include giant screen theaters, planetariums, DVD, and social social media. Launch is targeted for 2016.

Learning outcomes will focus on increasing awareness and interest in the LHC and increasing young people's engagement and excitement about the nature of scientific discovery. The research on girl's engagement and interest in physics will fill a gap in field.  

The project deliverables are projected to reach large audiences through national distribution of the giant screen film, the planetarium show, the exhibit, 3D/2D Blu Ray and DVDs, and access on computers, tablets, and other mobile devices.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
With funding from the National Science Foundation, Secrets of the Universe is a multimedia project that has at its core a 40-minute 3D giant screen film directed by a collaboration of K2 Communications Inc., The Stephen Low Company, and University of California Davis Department of Physics. The film gives viewers an inside look at the largest scientific instrument ever built, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), while introducing past and present scientists who have worked to understand the fundamental nature of the universe. Secrets of the Universe utilizes live-action footage filmed at the LHC facility, stunning scientific visualizations, and artistic interpretation to reveal some of the most compelling scientific stories of our time----recreation of the conditions that occurred immediately following the Big Bang, and the discovery of the Higgs boson. The film was recognized with a number of festival accolades (listed on film website), for the outstanding quality of both its science content and visuals.

The film is designed for general audiences who watch the film at local science centers and specialty theaters, and also for middle school students who watch the film as part of a museum field trip. Audience research with 6th graders helped shape the film. Further input was sought from youth advisors and media experts, with the aim of expanding STEM access to girls.

Intellectual Merit

Although facilities such as the LHC are integral to international scientific advancement, according to the American Physical Society much of the U.S. public is unaware of their importance. It is particularly crucial to engage American youth, many of whom have heard of the Big Bang and the Higgs boson and are already forming initial conceptions, but without an accurate understanding of how new technology and international collaboration is yielding new information about our Universe and its relevance to our lives.

Our innovative approach incorporates 1) the scale and visual/visceral power of the Giant Screen to enhance learning, 2) the parallel production of a digital full dome planetarium version of the film, 3) learning research on audience interests and motivations around the LHC and its experiments and discoveries, including research on school age girls 4) a content focus on scientific discovery, 5) use of art and music to animate LHC science, and 6) building capacity among informal educators to engage the public in this emerging research. 

The primary products include an IMAX/Giant Screen film also versioned for TV, DVD, and full dome planetariums, educational website with materials for teachers, virtual learning sessions hosted with museum partners for the public, and social media content centered around film topics. To support and extend the impact of the film for audiences, the project features an educational website with a variety of resources, including:

  • Award-winning videos of science content and diverse scientist role models from the film, which was shown to enhance youth learning by independent research that was part of the project. 
  • An online interactive experience, created with the help of the Perimeter Institute, for further exploration of observatories and scientific instruments featured in the film: how they work, what they discovered, why they matter, and the scientists involved.  
  • Classroom experiments and activities covering K-12, aligned to Next Generation Science Standards, and written under the advisory of the Perimeter Institute

Broader Impacts

The greater societal impact of the project is the production of a research-based IMAX/Giant Screen film to help adults and youth develop awareness of the LHC and interest in the thrill of discovery that the experiments contribute toward understanding of our Universe.

This project demonstrated the utility of an IMAX/Giant Screen film to engage and inspire youth, including girls and other underrepresented minorities, in high-energy particle physics, and in STEM in general. The research pointed to specific aspects of the project that effectively engaged middle school youth in complex science, including: 1) presenting an historical context by creating or pointing educators to additional supplemental materials that highlight the work of scientists past and present, and 2) creating science content and scientist character videos as pre-film playlists for middle school students.

Outreach to youth, including girls and other underrepresented minorities, included appearances and Q&A by Manuel, and working with community nonprofits to bring young people to see the film. These audiences responded positively to the film and to Manuel as a film and STEM ambassador. Their feedback and comments reflected the immersive nature of the film experience, and heightened curiosity around the film's science characters and content. As documented by the summative evaluation and research, a diversity of young people were inspired to consider particle physics as a topic for further learning and careers, with the potential to broaden participation in STEM.
